message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Proceedings of the 55th Annual ACM Symposium on Theory of Computing
Paper Abstract: The papers in this volume were presented at the 55th Annual ACM Symposium on Theory of Computing (STOC 2023), sponsored by the ACM Special Interest Group on Algorithms and Computation Theory (SIGACT). The conference was held in Orlando, Florida, as part of the ACM Federated Computing Research Conference (FCRC). The papers were presented as live talks during sessions held between June 20-23, 2023. STOC 2023 was part of Theory Fest, which included a range of panels, meetings, and social activities. FCRC 2023 featured plenary talks given by Kunle Olukotun, Margaret Martonosi, Shafi Goldwasser, Don Towsley, and Torsten Hoefler.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here's what I found about the Association for Computing Machinery:

## Overview

The Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) is an international learned society for computing founded on September 15, 1947, and headquartered in New York City.(no content)It is the world's largest scientific and educational computing society.

## Membership

The ACM is a non-profit professional membership group, reporting nearly 110,000 student and professional members as of 2024.

## Organization Structure

ACM is organized into over 180 local professional chapters and 38 Special Interest Groups (SIGs), through which it conducts most of its activities. Additionally, there are over 680 student chapters.(no content)Many of the SIGs, such as SIGGRAPH, SIGDA, SIGPLAN, SIGCSE and SIGCOMM, sponsor regular conferences, that serve as major publication venues in their respective fields. The groups also publish a large number of specialized journals, magazines, and newsletters.

## Recognition Programs

The ACM Fellows Program was established by Council of the Association for Computing Machinery in 1993 "to recognize and honor outstanding ACM members for their achievements in computer science and information technology and for their significant contributions to the mission of the ACM."

Here's what I found about the Association for Computing Machinery:

## Overview

The Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) is an international learned society for computing founded on September 15, 1947, and headquartered in New York City.(no content)It is the world's largest scientific and educational computing society.

## Membership

The ACM is a non-profit professional membership group, reporting nearly 110,000 student and professional members as of 2024.

## Organization Structure

ACM is organized into over 180 local professional chapters and 38 Special Interest Groups (SIGs), through which it conducts most of its activities. Additionally, there are over 680 student chapters.(no content)Many of the SIGs, such as SIGGRAPH, SIGDA, SIGPLAN, SIGCSE and SIGCOMM, sponsor regular conferences, that serve as major publication venues in their respective fields. The groups also publish a large number of specialized journals, magazines, and newsletters.

## Recognition Programs

The ACM Fellows Program was established by Council of the Association for Computing Machinery in 1993 "to recognize and honor outstanding ACM members for their achievements in computer science and information technology and for their significant contributions to the mission of the ACM."

Links: [{"title":"Computational complexity theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_complexity_theory"},{"title":"Category:Computational complexity theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Computational_complexity_theory"},{"title":"Computational complexity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_complexity"},{"title":"Talk:Computational complexity theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Computational_complexity_theory"},{"title":"Quantum complexity theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_complexity_theory"},{"title":"List of computability and complexity topics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_computability_and_complexity_topics"},{"title":"Implicit computational complexity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Implicit_computational_complexity"},{"title":"Reduction (complexity) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reduction_(complexity)"},{"title":"NP (complexity) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NP_(complexity)"},{"title":"Blum axioms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blum_axioms"}]

I found comprehensive search results about Computational Complexity Theory. Here's an overview:

## What is Computational Complexity Theory?

Computational complexity theory focuses on classifying computational problems according to their resource usage, and explores the relationships between these classifications.(no content)One of the roles of computational complexity theory is to determine the practical limits on what computers can and cannot do.

## Key Concepts

**Problems vs. Algorithms**: A key distinction between analysis of algorithms and computational complexity theory is that the former is devoted to analyzing the amount of resources needed by a particular algorithm to solve a problem, whereas the latter asks a more general question about all possible algorithms that could be used to solve the same problem.

**Complexity Measures**: Time complexity is generally expressed as the number of required elementary operations on an input of size n, where elementary operations are assumed to take a constant amount of time on a given computer and change only by a constant factor when run on a different computer.(no content)Space complexity is generally expressed as the amount of memory required by an algorithm on an input of size n.

**Decision Problems**: Decision problems are one of the central objects of study in computational complexity theory. A decision problem is a type of computational problem where the answer is either yes or no (alternatively, 1 or 0).

## Major Problems

The P versus NP problem, one of the seven Millennium Prize Problems, is part of the field of computational complexity.

The search results provide foundational information about the field, its key concepts, and important open problems in the theory.

Web search results for query: "Theory of Computing"

Links: [{"title":"Theory of computation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theory_of_computation"},{"title":"Theoretical computer science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theoretical_computer_science"},{"title":"Theory of Computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theory_of_Computing"},{"title":"Introduction to the Theory of Computation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Introduction_to_the_Theory_of_Computation"},{"title":"Category:Theory of computation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Theory_of_computation"},{"title":"Computer science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_science"},{"title":"Theory of Computing Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theory_of_Computing_Systems"},{"title":"Simons Institute for the Theory of Computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simons_Institute_for_the_Theory_of_Computing"},{"title":"Computational complexity theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_complexity_theory"},{"title":"Symposium on Theory of Computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symposium_on_Theory_of_Computing"}]

Here are the search results for "Theory of Computing":

## Overview

The theory of computation is the branch that deals with what problems can be solved on a model of computation using an algorithm, how efficiently they can be solved and to what degree (e.g., approximate solutions versus precise ones).

## Main Branches

The field encompasses several key areas:

1. **Automata Theory**: Automata theory is the study of abstract machines (or more appropriately, abstract 'mathematical' machines or systems) and the computational problems that can be solved using these machines. These abstract machines are called automata.

2. **Formal Language Theory**: Formal language theory is a branch of mathematics concerned with describing languages as a set of operations over an alphabet. It is closely linked with automata theory, as automata are used to generate and recognize formal languages.

3. **Computability Theory**: Computability theory deals primarily with the question of the extent to which a problem is solvable on a computer.

4. **Computational Complexity Theory**: Computational complexity theory considers not only whether a problem can be solved at all on a computer, but also how efficiently the problem can be solved. Two major aspects are considered: time complexity and space complexity, which are respectively how many steps it takes to perform a computation, and how much memory is required to perform that computation.

## Historical Development

Some pioneers of the theory of computation were Ramon Llull, Alonzo Church, Kurt Gödel, Alan Turing, Stephen Kleene, Rózsa Péter, John von Neumann and Claude Shannon.

The field has established itself as an independent academic discipline with major conferences like STOC and FOCS, and prestigious awards recognizing contributions to the field.

## Search Results for "Algorithm"

Based on the web search, here's what I found about algorithms:

### Definition
In mathematics and computer science, an algorithm is a finite sequence of mathematically rigorous instructions, typically used to solve a class of specific problems or to perform a computation.(no content)Algorithms are used as specifications for performing calculations and data processing.

### Key Characteristics
Starting from an initial state and initial input, the instructions describe a computation that, when executed, proceeds through a finite number of well-defined successive states, eventually producing "output" and terminating at a final ending state.(no content)Some algorithms, known as randomized algorithms, incorporate random input.

### Historical Background
The earliest evidence of algorithms is found in ancient Mesopotamian mathematics, with a Sumerian clay tablet found in Shuruppak near Baghdad and dated to c. 2500 BC describing the earliest division algorithm. The word itself has an interesting etymology: Around 825 AD, Persian scientist Muḥammad ibn Mūsā al-Khwārizmī wrote texts on Hindu-Arabic numerals and arithmetic, and Latin translations of these texts appeared in the early 12th century.

### Types of Algorithms
The search results include information about various specific algorithms such as:
- A* (pronounced "A-star") is a graph traversal and pathfinding algorithm that is used in many fields of computer science due to its completeness, optimality, and optimal efficiency.
- A greedy algorithm is any algorithm that follows the problem-solving heuristic of making the locally optimal choice at each stage.
- The Euclidean algorithm calculates the greatest common divisor (GCD) of two natural numbers.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Symposium on Theory of Computing STOC"

Links: [{"title":"Symposium on Theory of Computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symposium_on_Theory_of_Computing"},{"title":"Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FOCS"},{"title":"Theoretical computer science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theoretical_computer_science"},{"title":"Ivan Damgård - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ivan_Damg%C3%A5rd"},{"title":"List of computer science conference acronyms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_computer_science_conference_acronyms"},{"title":"STOC - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/STOC"},{"title":"International Colloquium on Automata, Languages and Programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Colloquium_on_Automata,_Languages_and_Programming"},{"title":"List of computer science conferences - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_computer_science_conferences"},{"title":"Category:Theoretical computer science conferences - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Theoretical_computer_science_conferences"},{"title":"Symposium on Theoretical Aspects of Computer Science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symposium_on_Theoretical_Aspects_of_Computer_Science"}]

Here are the key findings about STOC (Symposium on Theory of Computing):

## Overview
The Annual ACM Symposium on Theory of Computing (STOC) is an academic conference in the field of theoretical computer science.(no content)STOC has been organized annually since 1969, typically in May or June; the conference is sponsored by the Association for Computing Machinery special interest group SIGACT.

## Significance
STOC and its annual IEEE counterpart FOCS (the Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science) are considered the two top conferences in theoretical computer science.(no content)The acceptance rate of STOC, averaged from 1970 to 2012, is 31%, with the rate of 29% in 2012.

## Awards and Recognition
The Gödel Prize for outstanding papers in theoretical computer science is presented alternately at STOC and at the International Colloquium on Automata, Languages and Programming (ICALP); the Knuth Prize for outstanding contributions to the foundations of computer science is presented alternately at STOC and at FOCS.(no content)Since 2003, STOC has presented one or more Best Paper Awards to recognize papers of the highest quality at the conference.

## Notable Contributions
Early seminal papers in STOC include Cook (1971), which introduced the concept of NP-completeness.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title, relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
